PFTBLD(8) System Manager's Manual PFTBLD(8)

NAME

pftbld — automate pf(4) table content management

SYNOPSIS

pftbld [-dnuv] [-f file] [-s socket]

pftbld [-v] -p socket

DESCRIPTION

The pftbld daemon listens on UNIX-domain sockets for incoming IP addresses, usually sent by programs such as network services and applications, and makes them traverse pf(4) tables according to its configuration and the history of their occurrance. The daemon was originally designed to maintain service/application specific firewall blacklists, but may just as well serve any other kind of filtering or translation purposes. As pftbld can persist managed addresses and meta-data, it is capable of restoring its runtime status and corresponding pf(4) tables through system reboots and migrations.

pftbld obtains its configuration from pftbld.conf(5).

Sole prerequisite for client programs is the ability to directly or indirectly connect and write to UNIX-domain sockets. A FastCGI supported httpd(8) server reporting offenders through such a socket is a typical example (see also pftbld.conf(5)).

pftbld rereads the configuration file when it receives SIGHUP and reopens its log file when it receives SIGUSR1.

The options are as follows:

-d
Debug mode. Don't detach or become a daemon. This allows for easy monitoring of pftbld.
-f file
Specifies the configuration file. The default is /etc/pftbld/pftbld.conf.
-n
Verify the configuration, but don't start the service.
-p socket
Makes pftbld act as a pipe forwarding stdin to the UNIX-domain socket specified and terminates silently right after. No other actions will be carried out and no other files will be accessed.
-s socket
Specifies the control socket. Defaults to /var/run/pftbld.sock.
-u
By default, managed addresses will remain in pf(4) tables after pftbld shutdown. With this option given, addresses will be unloaded from corresponding tables on shutdown.
-v
Verbose mode. If used with the server, multiple -v options increase the verbosity. If used with pipe mode to write commands to the control socket, this will enable printing server replies to stdout.

MESSAGES

Messages may be sent to any socket specified in the configuration. Each message must be formatted as one single plain text string, and may consist of multiple newline-delimited parts. By default, the maximum length of a message is 2048 bytes, but this may be changed via the datamax parameter in pftbld.conf(5).

A message for a data socket must start with an IP address followed by an arbitrary number of optional text sections, whose sole purpose is getting matched against the exclude keyterms specified in the configuration and finally get written into the log file. Here's an example:

# msg="11.22.33.44\nGET /test.php 404"

Sending the above message to a data socket, in this case located at /var/www/run/pftbld-www.sock,

# echo -n "${msg}" | pftbld -p /var/www/run/pftbld-www.sock

which is connected to the www target, will cause two log entries:

[...] Hit :: [www] <- [11.22.33.44][GET /test.php 404]
[...] >>> Added [11.22.33.44]:[www]:(2x:3h16m25s) \
to { attackers } for 1h.

The first entry documents the incoming message including all optional parts. The following entry lets us know that this is the second time the address 11.22.33.44 was reported, while the last time was exaclty 3 hours, 16 minutes and 25 seconds ago. Finally, we learn that the address was added into the attackers table where it will remain for 1 hour before, in turn, getting deleted causing another log entry:

[...] >>> Deleted [11.22.33.44]:[www]:(2x:1h) from { attackers }.

Even though sending messages to a control socket basically works the same way, it is recommended to use the pftblctl(8) tool for the sake of simplicity. A list of accepted commands is available on its manpage.

FILES

/etc/pftbld/pftbld.conf
Default configuration file.
/var/log/pftbld.log
Default log file.
/var/run/pftbld.sock
Default control socket.

SEE ALSO

pf(4), pftbld.conf(5), pftblctl(8)

HISTORY

The pftbld program first appeared on GitHub in August, 2020.
